top_ideas.description: Spinoza argued that there is only one substance in the universe, which he identified as God or Nature ('Deus sive Natura'). Everything else (including minds and bodies) are modes (modifications) of this one substance.

God is not a transcendent being separate from the world but is identical with the natural world. Spinoza rejected anthropomorphic conceptions of God and instead defined God as the infinite, self-caused, necessary substance that constitutes reality.
Spinoza held that everything that happens is a necessary result of the nature of God or Nature. There is no free will in the traditional sense; all things follow from divine necessity.
Every being strives to persevere in its existence according to its own nature. This striving, or 'conatus', is the essence of each thing and forms the basis of Spinoza's ethical psychology.

Spinoza rejected Cartesian dualism. Instead, he proposed that the mind and the body are two attributes of the same substance. For every physical event, there is a corresponding mental eventâ€”without causality between them.

True blessedness comes from the intellectual love of God (amor Dei intellectualis), which arises from understanding the unity of all things within the divine substance. This love is eternal and forms the highest good.

Though everything is determined, human freedom consists in understanding the necessity of nature. The more we act according to reason and understand our place in the natural order, the freer we become.

top_ideas.idea: Critique of Superstition and Organized Religion
top_ideas.description: Spinoza argued that religion often degenerates into superstition, manipulated by authorities to control people. He advocated for a rational understanding of Scripture and religion grounded in ethical living rather than dogma.
Spinoza supported democratic governance and robust freedom of thought and expression. He believed a free state is one where individuals can reason and speak openly without fear of persecution.

Spinoza identified three levels of knowledge: imagination (based on sense experience), reason (rational understanding), and intuitive knowledge (direct insight into the essence of things, especially God). The higher the kind of knowledge, the more perfect the mind.
